task: The user has been unable to send MMS messages using their messaging app for the past few hours. Customer name: John Smith, phone number: 555-123-2002, current location: abroad in France. They will consider the issue resolved when an MMS message can be successfully sent.

messages.content: Hi! I'm having trouble sending MMS messages from my phone. It just started a few hours ago, and nothing seems to be going through. Could you help me fix this?

I can help you get MMS working again. To get started, I need to verify your account. Please provide one of the following:
- Your phone number
- Your customer ID
- Your full name and date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)

Once verified, I‚Äôll run a few quick checks and guide you through fixes. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôll do after identification:
- Check for basic cellular service and signal
- Make sure mobile data is turned on (MMS needs it)
- Ensure the network isn‚Äôt stuck on 2G
- Verify your APN settings (especially the MMSC URL)
- Check if Wi‚ÄëFi Calling is on and temporarily turn it off if needed
- Confirm your messaging app has storage and SMS permissions

If you want, you can also share a bit more info now:
- Can you still make/receive calls?
- Are you at home, or traveling/roaming?
- Do you have Wi‚ÄëFi on? If so, does web browsing work over cellular?

After you confirm your account details, I‚Äôll walk you through step by step.
messages.reasoning_content: Plan: First verify user identity as required for technical support. Then guide the user through diagnostics: check cellular service (status bar/signal), ensure mobile data is ON, verify network not on 2G, check APN settings, check Wi-Fi Calling status (may interfere with MMS), and check messaging app permissions. If needed, toggle Wi-Fi Calling off, reset APN settings and reboot, or adjust network mode preference. If line suspension or data limits are suspected, investigate customer account and line after identification.

messages.content:
Sure! My name is John Smith and my phone number is 555-123-2002. I‚Äôm currently traveling abroad in France.

I can make calls, but I haven‚Äôt tried browsing over cellular yet. Wi-Fi is on and working, but I mainly use mobile data for messaging. Let me know what you need me to check next.

Then we need to confirm the line is roaming enabled since traveling abroad, and mobile data needs to be on and roaming toggled. Also check data usage limits; if data is exhausted, MMS won‚Äôt work. Start with customer lookup, then get data usage and line details to check roaming enabled, status, plan data limits.

messages.content: Roaming enabled successfully

Thanks, John. I‚Äôve located your account and found the line tied to 555-123-2002. Since you‚Äôre in France, I‚Äôve just enabled international roaming on that line. Now we‚Äôll need to adjust a couple of settings on your phone and run quick checks.

Please follow these steps in order:

1) Turn on mobile data (if it‚Äôs off)
- On your phone: Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Mobile Data = ON

2) Turn on data roaming (required abroad)
- Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Data Roaming = ON

3) Temporarily turn off Wi‚ÄëFi Calling
- Settings > Phone or Mobile > Wi‚ÄëFi Calling = OFF
(Rationale: some carriers don‚Äôt support MMS over Wi‚ÄëFi Calling.)

4) Check your status bar and network
- Open your notifications/status bar and let me know what you see:
  - Signal strength (bars)
  - Network type shown (e.g., 5G, 4G/LTE)
  - Whether ‚ÄúData‚Äù/Mobile Data icon is present

5) Run a quick test
- If you can, try browsing a webpage over cellular to confirm data works.

If you‚Äôre ready, I can also walk you through the guided checks to spot any remaining issues. Just say ‚ÄúRun checks,‚Äù and I‚Äôll have you:
- Verify the APN settings (especially MMSC URL)
- Confirm network isn‚Äôt stuck on 2G
- Ensure the Messaging app has storage and SMS permissions

A couple of quick questions while you start:
- After turning on data roaming, does the signal show a usable connection?
- Does cellular web browsing work now?

We‚Äôll adjust as needed based on what you see.
messages.reasoning_content: We have identified the line and enabled roaming. Next, guide the user to enable device-side data roaming and mobile data, then run diagnostics: check_status_bar, check_network_status, check_data_restriction_status, check_apn_settings, check_wifi_calling_status, can_send_mms. If needed, reset APN and reboot. After tool enables roaming, ask user to confirm. Keep steps minimal.

Let me know what to do next. Should I try browsing a webpage over cellular?

Thanks for the details. Being on 2G with poor signal can prevent MMS from working. Let‚Äôs address that step by step.

1) Test cellular connectivity
- Please try browsing a webpage over cellular. Let me know if it loads or if you get ‚Äúno connection‚Äù or very slow behavior.

2) Switch network mode away from 2G
- On your phone: Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Network Mode / Preferred Network Type
- Choose an option that includes 4G or 5G. If you see ‚Äú5G/4G/Auto‚Äù or similar, select that.
- If you only see 2G/3G/4G options, pick 4G/LTE preferred.

After changing this:
- Wait up to 2 minutes to see if the signal improves and the indicator moves to 4G/LTE or 5G.

3) Let me run guided checks on your phone
- Say ‚ÄúRun checks,‚Äù and I‚Äôll have you:
  - Verify APN settings (especially the MMSC URL)
  - Confirm the Messaging app has storage and SMS permissions
  - Reset APN if needed and reboot to apply changes

If you‚Äôd prefer, we can first see how step 1 and 2 go and then proceed. When you‚Äôre ready, share:
- Did the webpage load over cellular?
- After changing network mode, does the status bar now show 4G/LTE or 5G and a better signal?
messages.reasoning_content: User enabled data roaming; MMS may be failing due to being on 2G, poor signal, and possible APN/MMSC issues. Next: prompt user to try browsing to test connectivity; then change network preference to 4G/5G preferred, check APN/MMSC, reset APN if needed, reboot, and retest MMS. Prepare to run guided checks with the tech tools if they consent.

I tried browsing a webpage over cellular, but there was no connection; the speed test failed.

However, I‚Äôve switched my network mode to prefer 4G/5G. The status bar now shows:
- Signal: Excellent
- Network: 5G
- Mobile Data: Enabled

What would you like me to check or try next?

Great progress‚Äî5G with excellent signal is exactly what we want. Now let‚Äôs focus on settings needed for MMS.

Please perform these guided checks one by one and tell me the results:

1) Check APN settings (MMSC URL)
- This is crucial for picture/video messaging.
- On your phone: Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Cellular Network > APN / Access Point Names
- Open the active APN entry and look for MMSC or MMSC URL.
- Report back:
  - Is there an MMSC URL listed? (Example format: http://mms.carrier.com)
  - If there are multiple APNs, which one is selected/active?

2) Check Messaging app permissions
- On your phone: Settings > Apps > Messaging/Messages > Permissions
- Confirm it has:
  - Storage (or Files and Media)
  - SMS
- Report back whether both are granted.

3) Check for VPN
- If you use a VPN app, turn it off temporarily.
- Otherwise, tell me if you see any VPN icon or if any VPN is connected.

4) Optional but helpful
- Temporarily turn Wi‚ÄëFi OFF, just for the test, then try sending an MMS.
- Also try sending a simple MMS with a small photo to test.

Based on what you report, I‚Äôll guide you to:
- Reset APN to defaults if the MMSC is missing/incorrect
- Grant any missing permissions
- Disconnect any VPN

Let me know what you find in steps 1‚Äì3, and the result of the test MMS.
messages.reasoning_content: User now shows 5G with excellent signal. Next steps to fix MMS: ensure APN is correct and MMSC URL is set, check messaging app permissions, toggle VPN off if present, and optionally toggle Wi-Fi off and reset network settings (APN reset and reboot). I‚Äôll ask the user to run the diagnostic checks via the available phone-side actions: check_apn_settings, check_app_permissions for messaging, check_vpn_status. Then, if APN is missing/incorrect, use reset_apn_settings and reboot_device. If VPN is on, disconnect it. If messaging lacks permissions, grant storage and sms. After changes, test sending an MMS and, if needed, have them toggle Wi-Fi off and try again.

Thanks for the update‚Äîyour APN settings look correct with the MMSC URL present, and VPN is off. Let‚Äôs pinpoint the messaging app and complete the permission check.

Finding and checking the messaging app:
- If you don‚Äôt see an app named exactly ‚ÄúMessaging,‚Äù look for these typical names:
  - Messages (default on many phones)
  - Google Messages
  - Samsung Messages
  - The one you use to send texts and see your conversations
- Open Settings > Apps (or Applications), then scroll to find one of those. If multiple messaging apps exist, select the one you normally use.
- In that app‚Äôs permissions, confirm it has:
  - Storage (or Files and Media)
  - SMS

If you‚Äôre still unsure which app it is, try this:
- Open your texting app (the one with your conversation list), tap an existing chat, and look in the three-dot menu for an ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù or ‚ÄúApp info‚Äù option. That will take you directly to the correct app page to check permissions.

Next quick tests:
- Temporarily turn Wi‚ÄëFi OFF and try sending a small picture via MMS.
- If it still fails, try sending an MMS with Wi‚ÄëFi ON but keep Wi‚ÄëFi Calling OFF.

If you‚Äôd like, I can also look at your installed app list and check permissions for the messaging app directly. Just say ‚ÄúShow my apps,‚Äù and I‚Äôll guide you through identifying the right one and ensuring permissions are set.

Please let me know:
- Which messaging app you found, and whether Storage and SMS are both granted
- The result of the small MMS test (sent or failed)

messages.reasoning_content: Next steps for MMS failure with correct APN, permissions, VPN off, Wi‚ÄëFi Calling off, 5G active: reset APN settings, reboot device, retest MMS; if still fails, suggest removing battery/SIM reseat, enable/disable airplane mode; check if data roaming is enabled on device and line (already enabled). Consider toggling airplane mode off-on to re-register. Also try re-enabling Wi‚ÄëFi Calling if still fails later. If still fails, escalate to technical support.

messages.content: Roaming was already enabled

Since everything looks correct on the surface, let‚Äôs do a couple of resets and re-register the network, then retest MMS.

Please follow these steps in order:

1) Reset APN settings and reboot
- Reset APN to defaults:
  - Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Cellular Network > APN / Access Point Names
  - Tap the three-dot menu and choose Reset to default, or Reset APNs
  - Select the correct carrier APN once the list refreshes (usually auto-selected)
- Reboot your phone completely after the reset.

2) Toggle Airplane Mode to re-register on the network
- After reboot, swipe down and turn Airplane Mode ON
- Wait 10 seconds, then turn Airplane Mode OFF
- Wait up to 2 minutes for signal to settle

3) Quick retest MMS
- With Wi‚ÄëFi OFF, try sending a small picture again
- Also try receiving an MMS from a contact if possible

If it still fails after the above:
- Toggle Wi‚ÄëFi Calling OFF (should already be OFF) and try again
- Try a different contact or carrier to rule out a recipient-side issue

If it still does not send after these steps, the next checks would be:
- Reseat the SIM card (if you‚Äôre comfortable doing that)
- Ensure no carrier account blocks or restrictions are affecting MMS abroad

Let me know the results of:
- The APN reset and reboot
- The airplane mode toggle
- The test MMS after those steps

Based on that, I‚Äôll guide you through the next actions or escalate to technical support if needed.
messages.reasoning_content: Roaming already enabled. Next safe steps per policy: reset APN settings, then reboot, then retest MMS. If still fails, try toggling airplane mode to re-register network. If still fails, consider reseating SIM. If still fails after that, escalate to technical support per APN/SIM issues guidance.

I followed your steps:

- Reset APN settings to default and rebooted my phone.
- Turned Airplane Mode ON for 10 seconds, then OFF, and waited for signal to settle‚Äînow showing excellent 5G again.
- With Wi-Fi OFF, I tried sending a small picture via MMS, but unfortunately, it still did not go through. My messaging app still cannot send MMS messages.

Is there something else I can try? I‚Äôm starting to get a bit frustrated since the usual fixes aren‚Äôt working.

I understand the frustration‚Äîyou‚Äôve done everything right on the surface. Let‚Äôs take two final steps that often resolve persistent MMS issues when abroad.

Step 1: Reseat the SIM card
- Power off your phone completely.
- Remove the SIM card using a SIM eject tool.
- Inspect it briefly‚Äîno visible damage or dust.
- Reinsert the SIM firmly until it clicks in place.
- Power on the phone and wait 2‚Äì3 minutes for signal to stabilize.

Step 2: Verify precise APN details
Because some carriers require more than just the MMSC URL, please check and share the full APN profile:
- Settings > Mobile/Cellular > Cellular Network > APN / Access Point Names
- Open the active APN and report back:
  - APN name
  - MMSC URL
  - MMS proxy (if present)
  - MMS port (if present)
  - MCC (Mobile Country Code)
  - MNC (Mobile Network Code)

After reseating and confirming the APN details:
- Try one more MMS with Wi‚ÄëFi OFF.

If this still doesn‚Äôt work, there may be a carrier-side provisioning issue specific to your MMS profile while roaming. In that case, I can escalate you to a technical support specialist who can verify and reprovision the MMS settings on the network.

Please let me know:
- Did reseat the SIM help?
- The full APN details as listed above
- Result of the test MMS after these steps
messages.reasoning_content: User roaming-enabled line still cannot send MMS after APN reset and network re-registration. Next low-risk step is to reseat SIM and reboot. After that, gather exact carrier-specific APN details from the device to confirm MMSC and MMS parameters, as MMSC alone may not be sufficient. If MMS still fails and SIM reseat doesn‚Äôt help, consider network-side provisioning check. Maintain user reassurance and provide clear step-by-step instructions.
